questions.text: A previously healthy 30-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of pain during sexual intercourse for 6 months. She also reports frequent episodes of crampy pelvic pain that starts one day before menses and lasts for 7 days. Her symptoms are not relieved with pain medication. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 5 days. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her husband. She uses a combined oral contraceptive pill. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows rectovaginal tenderness. Cervical and urethral swabs are negative. Transvaginal ultrasonography shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CA-125 may be elevated in patients with endometriosis, but it is not useful for its diagnosis because it is a nonspecific finding associated with a number of conditions, including some that cause lower abdominal pain (e.g., ovarian tumors). CA-125 levels can be used instead to assess the response to therapy and detect recurrence of endometriosis following surgical therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

In the case of endometriosis, hysterectomy with or without bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is indicated as a last resort in patients with intractable pelvic pain despite repeated attempts at other forms of therapy (especially if the patient has already reached menopause). The diagnosis of endometriosis has not yet been confirmed, and this 30-year-old woman may also wish to remain fertile. Hysterectomy is therefore contraindicated.

C) CORRECT:

Laparoscopy is indicated for the definitive diagnosis of endometriosis in patients with a presumptive clinical diagnosis but inconclusive imaging findings, if there is no response to medical therapy, and/or to exclude malignancy. The diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of small, bluish endometriotic lesions (“powder-burn” appearance) in extra-uterine locations and histological examination of these lesions. Furthermore, laparoscopy is both diagnostic and therapeutic as it allows excision and ablation of endometrial implants.

D) INCORRECT:

Hysteroscopy is used to diagnose and treat submucosal uterine fibroids, uterine polyps, and intrauterine adhesions. Hysteroscopy has no benefit in the diagnosis or management of endometriosis, since the symptoms are caused by endometrial tissue abnormally located outside the uterus.

E) INCORRECT:

A CT of the abdomen and pelvis is less accurate in the diagnosis of endometriosis than other imaging modalities, such as transvaginal ultrasonography (already performed in this patient) and MRI. In patients with normal or equivocal ultrasound findings in whom surgery is being considered and/or deep infiltrating endometriosis is suspected, an MRI of the pelvis with or without IV contrast may be warranted.
questions.hint: This patient's chronic dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and rectovaginal tenderness raise concern for endometriosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has been unable to conceive for 3 years. Her husband's sperm count has been normal during this time. She has had episodic pelvic and back pain accompanied by painful diarrhea for 5 years. She reports having one episode per month on average, and each episode lasts 4–6 days. She takes ibuprofen for the pain, which provides some relief. Menses have occurred at regular 29-day intervals since menarche at the age of 14 years and last for 7 days. She is sexually active with her husband, and they do not use contraception. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic and bimanual examinations are normal. There is mild rectovaginal tenderness on digital rectal examination. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Activation of lymphatic cells and tissue damage in the intestinal walls
Loss of fallopian tube function following infection
Smooth muscle tumor arising from the myometrium
Endometrial tissue outside the uterine cavity
Increased secretion of androgens and luteinizing hormone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Activation of lymphatic cells in the intestinal walls is the underlying pathophysiology of Crohn disease, which manifests with episodic diarrhea. However, Crohn disease also manifests with other gastrointestinal symptoms such as right lower quadrant abdominal pain and/or a palpable mass, and constitutional symptoms, which are not seen in this patient. In addition, Crohn disease is not typically associated with infertility.

B) INCORRECT:

Loss of fallopian tube function following infection is the mechanism of infertility in chronic pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) due to a sexually transmitted infection (most commonly gonorrhea or chlamydia). PID can have a subclinical course, manifesting with subtle features such as pelvic pain rather than overt symptoms of PID (e.g., vaginal discharge, fever). However, the monthly recurring pattern of diarrhea and pelvic pain makes another cause of infertility more likely in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Uterine leiomyomas are the most common tumor of the female genital tract and can cause back and/or pelvic pain and reproductive abnormalities such as infertility. Predisposing factors include nulliparity and age 25–45 years. While leiomyomas can cause bowel symptoms (e.g., constipation), they are usually not associated with diarrhea. Symptomatic leiomyomas manifest with abnormal menstruation (e.g., heavy menstrual bleeding) and an enlarged, firm, and/or irregular uterus on bimanual pelvic examination, which are not seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Endometrial tissue outside the uterine cavity is the underlying mechanism of endometriosis. Like the endometrium within the uterine cavity, this tissue reacts to the hormone cycle by proliferating in response to estrogen. Symptoms depend on the location of the endometrial tissue and characteristically worsen before the onset of menses, emphasizing the importance of taking a menstrual history. Given this patient's recurring diarrhea and mild rectovaginal tenderness, rectovaginal endometriosis is the most likely diagnosis. Treatment options for endometriosis include NSAIDs and continuous combined hormonal contraceptives in patients not trying to conceive. Advanced treatments include estrogen-suppressing pharmacological treatment (e.g., GnRH agonists) to inhibit the growth of endometrial tissue, and surgical options (e.g., laparoscopic excision of the lesions).

Infertility in endometriosis is caused by inflammation and adhesions that can change pelvic anatomy, altering egg quality and impairing implantation. Normal findings on pelvic examination and imaging (e.g., transvaginal ultrasound, hysterosalpingography) do not rule out endometriosis. The management of infertility due to endometriosis depends on the severity and location of the disease and includes laparoscopic excision of the lesions and in vitro fertilization.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased androgen secretion and elevated luteinizing hormone are hallmarks of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), which is a leading cause of infertility. PCOS manifests with menstrual irregularities (e.g., primary or secondary amenorrhea, oligomenorrhea), insulin resistance and associated conditions (especially obesity), and/or skin conditions (e.g., hirsutism), which are not seen in this patient. In addition, PCOS is not associated with pelvic pain or diarrhea.

F) INCORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency (POI) causes infertility. POI is associated with abnormal menstrual bleeding and climacteric symptoms (e.g., vaginal dryness, night sweats, hot flashes), which are not seen in this patient. In addition, pelvic pain and diarrhea are not features of POI.
questions.hint: This patient's monthly episodes of back and pelvic pain and diarrhea are most likely related to her menstrual cycle.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively worsening episodic pelvic pain for the past 2 years. The pain starts a few days before her menstrual period and lasts for about 10 days. She rates the pain as a 4 on a 10-point scale; ibuprofen has not provided relief. Menses occur at regular 29-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. Her Pap smears have shown no abnormalities; the most recent Pap smear was 1 year ago. Medical history otherwise is unremarkable and she takes no routine medications. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. She has noticed that intercourse is often painful. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. Bimanual examination shows a normal-sized uterus and no palpable adnexal masses. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a 0.4 cm hypoechoic nodule on the uterosacral ligament. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cervical and urethral swabs are used to test for gonorrhea and chlamydia if pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is suspected. PID can manifest with pelvic pain and dyspareunia in sexually active patients. However, pelvic pain in patients with PID is not usually associated with menses. Moreover, this patient does not have other common features of PID (e.g., cervical discharge, cervical motion tenderness) or risk factors for PID (e.g., multiple sexual partners, unprotected sex).

B) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the pelvis is a second-line imaging study to evaluate for suspected endometriosis. This imaging modality can help to differentiate endometriotic lesions from similar findings (e.g., uterine fibroids, adenomyosis) if the diagnosis is uncertain and it can help to plan surgical intervention. As a presumptive diagnosis of endometriosis can already be made based on this patient's clinical presentation and TVUS findings, an MRI of the pelvis is not currently necessary.

C) INCORRECT:

Gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists (GnRH agonists) reduce severe pain associated with endometriosis. However, long-term GnRH agonist therapy is associated with hypoestrogenic side effects (e.g., osteopenia, hot flashes, vaginal dryness). Therefore, a different treatment option is preferred as first-line therapy for patients with suspected endometriosis. A 3-month course of GnRH agonists can be considered if first-line therapy fails to control the patient's symptoms and if other causes of chronic pelvic pain have been excluded.

D) CORRECT:

Continuous hormonal contraception (estrogen-progestin or progestogen-only contraceptives) together with NSAIDs is the first-line treatment in patients with endometriosis who do not want to conceive and have mild to moderate pelvic pain without complications. Continuous hormonal contraception stops the cyclical, estrogen-dependent growth of endometrial tissue, thereby reducing pelvic pain and the size of endometriotic lesions. Second-line treatment options include gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists and androgens. Surgery is indicated for patients with expanding endometriomas, infertility, and refractory symptoms despite medical therapy, or if there is diagnostic uncertainty (e.g., to exclude malignancy).

E) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopy confirms the diagnosis of endometriosis and is used to excise or ablate endometriotic lesions. However, because of the risks associated with general anesthesia and surgery, a less invasive treatment should be considered first. Surgery is indicated for patients with expanding endometriomas, infertility, refractory symptoms despite medical therapy, and when there is diagnostic uncertainty (e.g., to exclude malignancy).
questions.hint: In an individual of childbearing age, the combination of chronic episodic pelvic pain that worsens before the onset of menses, dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia suggests endometriosis. This patient's hypoechoic nodule on the uterosacral ligament seen on transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS) is most likely an endometriotic lesion.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has been unable to conceive for 2 years. The patient also reports monthly episodes of pelvic and back pain accompanied by painful diarrhea for 6 years. She takes naproxen for the pain, which has provided some relief. Menses have occurred at regular 28-day intervals since menarche at the age of 11 years and last for 7 days. She is sexually active with her husband and does not use contraception. Pelvic and rectal examination shows no abnormalities. A hysterosalpingogram is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Endometrial tissue outside the uterine cavity
Smooth muscle tumor arising from the myometrium
Increased secretion of androgens and luteinizing hormone
Activation of lymphatic cells in the intestinal walls

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterine cavity, most commonly in the fallopian tubes, ovaries, intestines, and/or bladder. Like the endometrium in the uterine cavity, this tissue reacts to the hormone cycle, proliferating under the influence of estrogen. Patients typically present with abdominal pain that worsens before the onset of menses. Depending on the location of the endometrial tissue, most likely rectovaginal in this case, symptoms such as diarrhea, dyschezia, and hematochezia can also occur.

Patients with endometriosis are usually treated with NSAIDs and continuous hormonal contraceptives. NSAIDs can be used alone if pregnancy is desired. In severe cases, GnRH agonists and estrogen-progestin OCPs may be indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Leiomyoma and leiomyosarcomas are smooth muscle tumors of the uterus that are usually small and asymptomatic. If symptoms do occur, they depend on the size and location of the tumor and can include abnormal menstruation. The exact mechanism of hypermenorrhea is not fully understood but probably involves abnormal venous drainage and prostaglandin production as well as enlargement of the uterine cavity. However, neither leiomyomas nor leiomyosarcomas are associated with diarrhea.

C) INCORRECT:

Primary ovarian failure causes anovulation, amenorrhea, and infertility. Although this patient has not been able to conceive for 2 years, she has a regular menstrual cycle. Moreover, primary ovarian failure is not usually associated with pelvic pain or diarrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) can be caused by pituitary gland dysfunction resulting from surgery, infarction, or tumor. Decreased GnRH secretion results in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Patients present with amenorrhea or irregular menstrual cycles due to low levels of FSH and LH. However, this patient's menstrual cycles have been regular.

E) INCORRECT:

Sexually transmitted infections, especially gonorrhea and/or chlamydia, can cause inflammation of the fallopian tubes and lead to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Chronic PID can also manifest with episodic pelvic pain and infertility (secondary to scarring of the fallopian tubes preventing ova transit to the uterus). However, a hysterosalpingogram would show a sudden interruption of contrast media if fallopian tube scarring was present. Furthermore, PID would not account for this patient's recurrent diarrhea.
Image Description:

Hysterosalpingogram

The tube is occluded at the isthmic portion of the fallopian tubes on both sides (arrows). Size and shape of the uterine cavity are inconspicuous.

These findings are consistent with bilateral tubal blockage.

F) INCORRECT:

Increased androgen secretion and elevated luteinizing hormone are characteristics of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Patients with PCOS present with hirsutism and anovulation. This patient, however, has regular menstrual cycles.

G) INCORRECT:

Activation of lymphatic cells in the intestinal walls is the underlying pathophysiology of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Although patients present with abdominal pain and diarrhea, as seen in this patient, IBD does not cause infertility. Moreover, the abdominal pain associated with IBD is independent of the menstrual cycle.
questions.hint: It is likely that this patient's episodes of diarrhea and pelvic and back pain occur at a certain time in her menstrual cycle.

questions.text: A 28-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. Upon questioning, she reports that she and her husband have been trying to conceive for more than 1 year; they have unprotected sexual intercourse 3–4 times per week. Recently, she has not been enjoying sexual intercourse with her husband because of painful penetration. She also reports episodic back and pelvic pain over the past 6 months that lasts for 2–3 days; she has missed several days of work each month because of the pain. Menarche was at the age of 13 years, and menses occur at 26–28 day intervals and last 3 days with normal flow. Pelvic examination shows a normal-appearing vulva and vagina. There is rectovaginal tenderness. Ultrasonography of the pelvis shows a retroverted normal-sized uterus. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Endometrial tissue within the myometrium on biopsy
Concentric, solid myometrial tumors on MRI

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adenomyosis is characterized by endometrial tissue within the uterine myometrium. The most common presenting symptoms include dysmenorrhea and/or heavy menstrual bleeding. Chronic pelvic pain, dyspareunia, and infertility are less common. Moreover, her ultrasonography shows a normal-sized uterus; patients with adenomyosis typically have a tender, uniformly enlarged uterus (rather than rectovaginal tenderness) and evidence of endometrial infiltration, smooth muscle proliferation, and increased vascularity on imaging studies.

B) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) manifests with multiple bilateral cystic proliferations within the ovaries. Although PCOS is associated with infertility, it does not typically cause dysmenorrhea, chronic pelvic pain, or dyspareunia. This patient also lacks typical manifestations of PCOS, such as irregular menses, obesity, hirsutism, and acne.

C) CORRECT:

Endometriosis is a gynecological condition affecting reproductive-aged women characterized by ectopic endometrial tissue. Patients commonly present with cyclic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, as well as infertility. Preliminary diagnosis of endometriosis is typically based on the patient's history, since most women have a normal physical examination. However, the most common findings include tenderness on palpation of the posterior vaginal fornix (i.e., rectovaginal tenderness) and a retroverted fixture (due to adhesions). Diagnosis is confirmed by laparoscopic visualization of endometrial implants outside the uterine cavity (e.g., peritoneal lesions with a reddish-blue appearance), with histological examination of biopsy specimens typically showing hemosiderin-laden macrophages with normal endometrial epithelium.
Image Description:

Laparoscopic image of the pelvic peritoneum

Red-black lesions distributed are seen over the peritoneum.

This appearance is characteristic of endometrial implants seen in endometriosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Uterine leiomyomas (fibroids) are benign smooth muscle tumors within the uterine wall that can cause dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, pelvic pain, and in severe cases, infertility. However, the most common presenting symptom in patients with uterine leiomyomas is abnormal menstrual bleeding; this patient, who has normal menses at 26–28 day intervals that last 3 days with normal flow, is unlikely to have this condition. In addition, pelvic examination typically shows an enlarged, irregularly-shaped uterus, which is not seen here. Moreover, ultrasound typically shows concentric, hypoechoic, heterogeneous masses located in or on the uterus.

E) INCORRECT:

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is a bacterial infection of the upper female reproductive tract that may be caused by an intracellular organism (e.g., Chlamydia trachomatis). PID can cause dysmenorrhea, chronic pelvic pain, dyspareunia, and infertility. However, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of PID, e.g., cervical motion tenderness, purulent vaginal and/or cervical discharge, or signs of infection on ultrasound (e.g., free fluid, abscesses, and/or pyosalpinx/hydrosalpinx).
questions.hint: The patient's infertility, dyspareunia, and cyclic pelvic pain suggest endometriosis.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman reports a 2-year history of chronic pelvic pain. She describes the pain as intermittent, throbbing, and more intense at the time of her menses. It radiates to her back on both sides. She has dyspareunia on deep penetration but no dysuria or dyschezia. She has had one pregnancy culminating in a full-term vaginal delivery and is not currently seeking another pregnancy.
On bimanual examination, she has diffuse tenderness, particularly on the left side. She has no palpable pelvic masses. A cervical smear is normal, and cervical cultures are negative. Urinalysis is within normal limits, and a pregnancy test is negative. The patient's BMI is 22.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: A trial of oral contraceptive pills and ibuprofen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trigger-point injections are used to diagnose and treat myofascial pathology.

B) CORRECT:

Pelvic endometriosis affects between 15% and 25% of all women of reproductive age. Although not all women with pelvic endometriosis have signs and symptoms of the disease, those who do often have chronic pelvic pain, dyspareunia, and debilitating menstrual periods. In severe cases, patients may also have symptoms related to involvement of the bowels or urinary system.

In the absence of palpable pelvic pathology, especially in a woman with a normal BMI and no current plans for pregnancy, pelvic pain can be treated empirically with hormonal contraceptive regimens (such as oral contraceptive pills, hormone-containing intrauterine devices, or injections of medroxyprogesterone acetate) in combination with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial strategy for a patient with chronic pelvic pain and suspected pelvic endometriosis who is not contemplating pregnancy is a trial of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs and hormonal contraception.

C) INCORRECT:

Although cystoscopy can be used as a part of the diagnostic process, it is generally reserved for patients with urinary symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

If the pain persists and is unresponsive to conservative medical management, the most appropriate next step is diagnostic laparoscopy.

E) INCORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasonography is indicated when palpable pelvic masses, such as endometriomas, are present. It does not detect peritoneal endometriosis. CT of the pelvis is not a first-line radiographic imaging option in this setting and would only be needed as follow-up if there was suspicion for cancer on ultrasound.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the office because she has been unable to conceive for 2 years. The patient also reports monthly episodes of pelvic and back pain accompanied by painful diarrhea for 6 years. She takes naproxen for the pain, which has provided some relief. Menses have occurred at regular 28-day intervals since menarche at the age of 11 years and last for 7 days. She is sexually active with her husband and does not use contraception. Pelvic and rectal examination shows no abnormalities. A hysterosalpingogram is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

B) INCORRECT:

Leiomyoma and leiomyosarcomas are smooth muscle tumors of the uterus that are usually small and asymptomatic. If symptoms do occur, they depend on the size and location of the tumor and can include abnormal menstruation. However, neither leiomyomas nor leiomyosarcomas are associated with diarrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Sexually transmitted infections, especially gonorrhea and/or chlamydia, can cause inflammation of the fallopian tubes and lead to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). However, a hysterosalpingogram would show a sudden interruption of contrast media if fallopian tube scarring was present. Furthermore, PID would not account for this patient's recurrent diarrhea.
Image Description:

Hysterosalpingogram

The tube is occluded at the isthmic portion of the fallopian tubes on both sides (arrows). Size and shape of the uterine cavity are inconspicuous.

These findings are consistent with bilateral tubal blockage.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased androgen secretion and elevated luteinizing hormone are characteristics of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Patients with PCOS present with hirsutism and anovulation. This patient, however, has regular menstrual cycles.
questions.hint: It is likely that this patient's episodes of diarrhea and pelvic and back pain occur at a certain time in her menstrual cycle.

This patient's hypoechoic nodule on the uterosacral ligament seen on transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS) is most likely an endometriotic lesion.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with six months of progressively worsening pelvic pain that peaks around her menses. She reports heavier-than-usual menstrual bleeding and difficulty conceiving for the past year. She denies any significant past medical history. Physical examination reveals a non-enlarged uterus that is difficult to move, with nodularity and tenderness along the uterosacral ligaments. Her last Pap smear was normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Uterine fibroids (leiomyomas) present with heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pain, typically with a palpable, irregularly enlarged uterus. The normal-sized, immobile uterus with uterosacral ligament nodularity indicates pelvic adhesions, not a mass effect. The cyclical pain and infertility suggest diffuse pelvic pathology, not fibroids.

B) CORRECT:

Endometriosis manifests with endometrial glands and stroma outside the uterine cavity, often on pelvic peritoneal surfaces like the uterosacral ligaments. The cyclic pelvic pain correlates with menstruation due to the hormonally responsive nature of ectopic implants, which thicken and slough off like normal endometrium. Chronic inflammation from these implants leads to fibrosis and adhesions, resulting in a fixed, nodular uterus and tenderness, especially along the uterosacral ligaments. The combination of dysmenorrhea, subfertility, and characteristic pelvic examination findings aligns with the pathophysiology of endometrial tissue outside its usual location.

Key learning point: Endometriosis is characterized by cyclic pelvic pain, heavy menstrual bleeding, infertility, and examination findings of a normal-sized, immobile uterus with nodularity and tenderness on the uterosacral ligaments.

C) INCORRECT:

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is an acute infectious process with pelvic pain, fever, and cervical motion tenderness. The chronicity of symptoms, pain peaking around menses, and heavy bleeding do not align with an acute infection. The non-enlarged uterus with nodularity and uterosacral ligament tenderness suggests chronic conditions with adhesions, not PID.

D) INCORRECT:

Adenomyosis involves endometrial tissue within the myometrium, typically causing dysmenorrhea and heavy menstrual bleeding. It usually results in a uniformly enlarged, boggy uterus, unlike the non-enlarged, nodular uterus with uterosacral ligament tenderness seen here. Pelvic fixation suggests adhesions, not typical of adenomyosis.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents with progressively worsening dysmenorrhea and pelvic pain. She has a 2-year history of secondary infertility and reports that the pain intensifies just before her menses. She also experiences painful intercourse. She has no significant medical history and denies any prior sexually transmitted infections. On examination, her uterus is retroverted and tender on bimanual palpation, with nodularity along the uterosacral ligaments. Laboratory evaluation, including inflammatory markers and complete blood count, is unremarkable (see report).
Pelvic ultrasound: Enlarged left ovary containing a 3-cm echogenic cystic lesion; no free fluid in the cul-de-sac
Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adenomyosis involves endometrial tissue within the myometrium, typically in multiparous women, causing a diffusely enlarged, tender uterus and heavy menstrual bleeding. The nodularity along the uterosacral ligaments and retroverted uterus suggest peritoneal or ovarian implantation, not intramyometrial invasion. The ovarian cystic lesion on imaging is inconsistent with adenomyosis, which lacks a uniformly enlarged, boggy uterus and heavy bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Leiomyomas, benign uterine smooth muscle tumors, often cause heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pressure. The cyclic pelvic pain, dyspareunia, and nodular uterosacral ligament findings are not typical of leiomyomas. Leiomyomas usually present as focal uterine masses, not ovarian cystic lesions, and the absence of abnormal bleeding further reduces the likelihood of leiomyoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) involves pelvic pain and infertility but typically presents with fever and elevated inflammatory markers, which are absent here. The lack of sexually transmitted infection history and the presence of nodularity along the uterosacral ligaments, rather than cervical motion tenderness, argue against PID. The isolated ovarian cystic lesion is not characteristic of PID-related adnexal masses.

D) CORRECT:

Endometriosis manifests with cyclic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia due to ectopic endometrial tissue that proliferates and bleeds in sync with the menstrual cycle. The ultrasound finding of an echogenic cystic lesion on the ovary suggests an endometrioma, a blood-filled cyst resulting from cyclic hemorrhage. Physical examination reveals a retroverted tender uterus and nodularity along the uterosacral ligaments, indicating adhesions and inflammatory fibrosis from ectopic endometrial tissue. These features contribute to secondary infertility and align with the pathophysiology of endometriosis, where ectopic implants induce local inflammation and fibrosis, disrupting normal pelvic anatomy.

Key learning point: Endometriosis is a common cause of secondary infertility in young women and is often associated with pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old nulliparous woman presents with six months of moderate to severe lower abdominal pain that worsens just before her period. She also experiences painful bowel movements during menstruation and occasional dyspareunia. She denies fever, abnormal vaginal discharge, or urinary complaints. She consistently uses barrier protection and has tested negative for sexually transmitted infections. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the posterior fornix with nodularity and restricted uterine mobility. A complete blood count is normal. She has attempted NSAIDs with minimal relief. Diagnostic laparoscopy is performed (see image).
Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) typically presents with lower abdominal pain, fever, and abnormal vaginal discharge, none of which are present here. The normal complete blood count and absence of infectious symptoms argue against PID. The cyclical nature of the pain and painful bowel movements suggest a hormonally mediated process.

B) CORRECT:

Endometriosis manifests with ectopic endometrial tissue outside the uterine cavity, responding to hormonal changes. The patient's age, nulliparity, and cyclic pelvic pain, worsening premenstrually, suggest endometriosis. Painful bowel movements during menstruation indicate possible bowel serosa involvement. Physical examination reveals posterior fornix tenderness, nodularity, and restricted uterine mobility, consistent with adhesions and fibrosis from inflammation, especially in the rectovaginal space, which is confirmed on laparoscopy.

Key learning point: Cyclic pelvic pain and dyschezia in a nulliparous woman are suggestive of endometriosis, a condition where endometrial-like tissue grows outside the uterus, often causing pain during menstruation and bowel movements.

C) INCORRECT:

Adenomyosis involves endometrial tissue within the myometrium, causing a diffusely enlarged, tender uterus and heavy menstrual bleeding menorrhagia) and dysmenorrhea. Laparoscopy in adenomyosis typically does not reveal pelvic adhesions or endometrial implants on the ovaries and peritoneal surfaces, as seen in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) presents with abdominal pain and altered bowel habits, but lacks the cyclical pain and menstrual association seen here. The physical examination findings of posterior fornix tenderness and nodularity, along with the adnexal adhesions seen on laparoscopy, indicate pelvic pathology, not IBS. IBS is a functional disorder without definitive pelvic findings or structural abnormalities.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents with progressively worsening dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain over the past year to the clinic. She also reports deep dyspareunia that has intensified over several months. She has tried NSAIDs with minimal relief. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the posterior vaginal fornix but no palpable masses (see report).
Transvaginal ultrasound: No pelvic abnormalities
Which of the following investigations is most appropriate to definitively confirm the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Diagnostic laparoscopy is the gold standard for confirming endometriosis, providing direct visualization of the pelvic cavity to identify peritoneal implants, adhesions, and deep infiltrative lesions. It allows for tissue biopsies for histopathological confirmation, ensuring accurate diagnosis even when imaging studies like transvaginal ultrasound show no abnormalities. Additionally, laparoscopy enables simultaneous therapeutic interventions, such as ablation or excision of endometriotic lesions, which can relieve symptoms and improve fertility outcomes. This procedure also assesses the extent and severity of the disease, aiding in comprehensive surgical planning and individualized patient management.

Key learning point: Laparoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis, allowing direct visualization of endometrial implants and lesions in the pelvis.

B) INCORRECT:

Hysterosalpingography assesses the uterine cavity and fallopian tube patency but does not visualize extrauterine structures like peritoneal surfaces. It is inadequate for detecting lesions implicated in chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and deep dyspareunia, as these are likely beyond the uterine lumen and fallopian tubes.

C) INCORRECT:

Serum CA 125 may be elevated in endometriosis but lacks specificity, as it can be elevated in various benign and malignant conditions. Its levels do not correlate well with the presence or severity of endometriosis, limiting its diagnostic utility. It serves as an adjunct marker rather than a primary confirmatory investigation.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI of the pelvis provides excellent soft tissue contrast and can identify deep infiltrative disease, especially in the uterosacral ligaments, bowel, or bladder. However, it is less reliable for detecting superficial peritoneal implants, which are common in endometriosis. MRI does not substitute for direct visualization and histological confirmation, which are essential for definitive diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old G2P2 woman presents with a 2-year history of progressively worsening dysmenorrhea and painful intercourse. She has no plans for future pregnancy. She has had limited relief with NSAIDs and does not tolerate hormonal therapies. On examination, she has left adnexal tenderness. She desires a definitive intervention but wishes to preserve ovarian function (see report).
Pelvic ultrasound: 4-cm left ovarian cyst with homogeneous low-level echoes, concerning for an endometrioma
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Percutaneous aspiration of the ovarian cyst
Laparoscopic cystectomy with ablation of endometriotic lesions

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs reduce prostaglandin-mediated pain and are first-line for dysmenorrhea. However, this patient has worsening symptoms and limited relief from NSAIDs, indicating a more complex pathology. The ultrasound suggests an endometrioma, which is less responsive to symptomatic treatment. Continued NSAID use does not address the structural lesion or pathological mechanisms, and the patient seeks definitive intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with hysterectomy removes both ovaries and the uterus, leading to surgical menopause and loss of ovarian function. This approach is inappropriate for a 40-year-old woman wishing to preserve ovarian hormonal function. While suitable for some endometriosis cases, it does not align with the patient's goals and exposes her to long-term effects of premature estrogen loss, such as cardiovascular and bone density issues.

C) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous aspiration may provide temporary relief for simple ovarian cysts but is inappropriate for endometriomas. The ultrasound findings suggest an endometrioma, which has a cyst wall lined by endometrial tissue. Aspiration does not remove this lining, leading to recurrence. Additionally, aspiration risks spillage of cyst contents, exacerbating pelvic inflammation and adhesions.

D) CORRECT:

Endometriomas are ovarian cysts formed by ectopic endometrial tissue, causing pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia. For symptomatic patients desiring definitive treatment while preserving ovarian function, laparoscopic cystectomy is optimal. This procedure removes the cyst wall while preserving normal ovarian tissue, reducing the risk of diminished ovarian reserve. Concurrent ablation of endometriotic lesions addresses pelvic adhesions and peritoneal implants, common pain contributors. Laparoscopy offers magnification, enhancing surgical precision and minimizing invasiveness. These strategies align with evidence-based practices for symptom relief and improved quality of life in endometriosis patients.

Key learning point: In women with symptomatic endometriomas who have completed childbearing, laparoscopic removal of the cyst with ablation of endometriotic lesions is an effective treatment option that addresses symptoms and preserves ovarian function.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents with a 1-year history of progressively worsening cyclical lower abdominal pain and painful menstrual periods. She has tried NSAIDs and combined oral contraceptives for 3 months with minimal relief. Pelvic examination reveals diffuse tenderness without palpable masses. Laboratory tests, including complete blood count and basic metabolic panel, are normal.
Which of the following demonstrates the highest diagnostic accuracy for confirming the suspected condition in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pelvic MRI provides detailed visualization of soft tissues and is useful for identifying deep infiltrating lesions and endometriomas. However, it is less effective for detecting small peritoneal implants and subtle lesions typical of early or moderate endometriosis. MRI findings can be nonspecific, leading to potential false negatives.

B) INCORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasound is useful for identifying ovarian endometriomas, which appear as 'ground glass' cysts. However, it is less effective for detecting peritoneal or deep infiltrative endometriosis, as these lesions are often small and variable in echogenicity. The patient's symptoms suggest peritoneal involvement, limiting the diagnostic accuracy of ultrasound.

C) CORRECT:

Endometriosis is characterized by ectopic endometrial tissue, often causing cyclical pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea. Pelvic laparoscopy with biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis, as it allows direct visualization of lesions and histologic confirmation by identifying endometrial glands and stroma. This procedure also enables therapeutic interventions, such as lesion ablation or excision, which can improve symptoms. While empirical treatment with NSAIDs and hormonal therapies is common, definitive diagnosis is necessary when symptoms persist, as in this patient.

Key learning point: Diagnostic laparoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis, as it allows direct visualization and biopsy of lesions.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum CA-125 levels may be elevated in endometriosis but have low sensitivity and specificity. CA-125 is a nonspecific marker that can be elevated in various conditions, including ovarian malignancies and pelvic inflammatory disease. In early or minimal endometriosis, CA-125 levels may remain normal, limiting its diagnostic utility.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old nulliparous woman presents with progressively worsening pelvic pain that peaks during her menstrual periods. She also experiences painful intercourse and occasional mid-cycle spotting. She has been attempting conception for over a year without success. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the posterior fornix and reduced uterine mobility. Laboratory investigations, including normal serum CA-125 and normal complete blood count, are unremarkable (see report).
Transvaginal ultrasound: Homogeneous, 4-cm right adnexal cyst and subtle nodular lesions near the uterosacral ligaments
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Laparoscopic surgical treatment of the ovarian cyst and endometriotic implants
In vitro fertilization without further intervention

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptives alleviate endometriosis-related pain by decreasing ovarian hormone production and limiting cyclical stimulation of ectopic endometrial tissue. However, they suppress ovulation, conflicting with conception attempts. In a patient with infertility, surgical management to excise endometriotic lesions is more appropriate.

B) CORRECT:

Laparoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing and managing endometriosis, allowing direct visualization and histologic confirmation of endometrial implants. This patient's symptoms—cyclical pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia—along with imaging findings of an ovarian endometrioma and nodular lesions near the uterosacral ligaments, suggest endometriosis. Laparoscopic surgery can excise or ablate endometriotic lesions, reduce pelvic adhesions, and restore normal pelvic anatomy, potentially improving fertility. This approach is suitable for patients trying to conceive, as it avoids the anti-estrogenic effects of hormonal therapies.

Key learning point: Endometriosis is a benign condition characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, often associated with pelvic pain and infertility.

C) INCORRECT:

Gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists suppress pituitary gonadotropins, reducing estrogen levels and causing regression of endometriotic lesions. However, they inhibit ovulation, which is counterproductive for women attempting conception. Surgical management is preferred to address endometriosis and improve fertility.

D) INCORRECT:

In vitro fertilization (IVF) is effective for infertility but does not address underlying pelvic pathology, such as endometriosis, which may affect fertility. Laparoscopy can confirm and treat endometriosis, improving the pelvic environment and optimizing receptivity for future conception attempts.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman presents with progressively worsening pelvic pain that begins a few days before her menstrual flow and continues through the first days of her period for the past six months. She has tried NSAIDs without significant relief. She is sexually active but does not desire pregnancy at this time. Physical examination shows tenderness in the lower abdomen without palpable masses (see report).
Pelvic ultrasound: No abnormalities
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

GnRH agonists reduce estrogen levels, alleviating symptoms of estrogen-dependent conditions like endometriosis. However, they are second-line treatments due to hypoestrogenic side effects, such as decreased bone density. They are typically used after first-line hormonal therapies, like COCs, have failed.

B) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs inhibit prostaglandin synthesis, reducing menstrual pain. However, the patient's pain persists despite NSAID use, indicating inadequate relief. Increasing the dose may not improve outcomes and poses risks like gastrointestinal irritation. The chronicity of symptoms suggests the need for a different treatment strategy.

C) CORRECT:

Endometriosis manifests with cyclic pelvic pain, often worsening before and during menstruation. Combined oral contraceptives (COCs) are effective in managing this pain by suppressing ovulation and reducing estrogen production, which decreases the proliferation of endometrial tissue. This hormonal suppression alleviates the cyclic inflammatory response and reduces endometriotic lesions. For a sexually active woman not seeking pregnancy, COCs provide a safe first-line treatment, especially when NSAIDs have been ineffective and imaging shows no pelvic abnormalities.

Key learning point: After NSAIDs, hormonal therapies such as oral contraceptive pills or oral progesterone are the next steps in managing endometriosis symptoms before considering surgical options.

D) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopy confirms and stages endometriosis but is invasive and reserved for cases where medical therapy fails or advanced disease is suspected. The patient's symptoms and normal imaging support empirical medical management with hormonal therapy before considering surgery.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of pain during sexual intercourse. She also reports frequent episodes of crampy pelvic pain that begin one day before her menses and last for 7 days. Her symptoms are not relieved by pain medication. Her menstrual cycles are regular every 28 days and last 5 days. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her husband and uses a combined oral contraceptive pill. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there is rectovaginal tenderness. Cervical and urethral swabs are negative. Transvaginal ultrasonography is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A CT of the abdomen and pelvis is less accurate in the diagnosis of endometriosis than other imaging modalities, such as transvaginal ultrasonography (already performed in this patient) and MRI. In patients with normal or equivocal ultrasound findings in whom surgery is being considered and/or deep infiltrating endometriosis is suspected, an MRI of the pelvis with or without IV contrast may be warranted.

B) INCORRECT:

In the case of endometriosis, hysterectomy with or without bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is indicated as a last resort in patients with intractable pelvic pain despite repeated attempts at other forms of therapy (especially if the patient has already reached menopause). The diagnosis of endometriosis has not yet been confirmed, and this 30-year-old woman may also wish to remain fertile. Hysterectomy is therefore contraindicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Hysteroscopy is used to diagnose and treat submucosal uterine fibroids, uterine polyps, and intrauterine adhesions. Hysteroscopy has no benefit in the diagnosis or management of endometriosis, since the symptoms are caused by endometrial tissue abnormally located outside the uterus.

D) INCORRECT:

CA-125 may be elevated in patients with endometriosis, but it is not useful for its diagnosis because it is a nonspecific finding associated with a number of conditions, including some that cause lower abdominal pain (e.g., ovarian tumors). CA-125 levels can be used instead to assess the response to therapy and detect recurrence of endometriosis following surgical therapy.

E) CORRECT:

Laparoscopy is indicated for the definitive diagnosis of endometriosis in patients with a presumptive clinical diagnosis but inconclusive imaging findings, if there is no response to medical therapy, and/or to exclude malignancy. The diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of small, bluish endometriotic lesions (“powder-burn” appearance) in extra-uterine locations and histological examination of these lesions. Furthermore, laparoscopy is both diagnostic and therapeutic as it allows excision and ablation of endometrial implants.

Key learning point: Laparoscopy is the gold standard for definitive diagnosis and potential treatment of endometriosis when clinical suspicion is high but imaging is inconclusive.
questions.hint: This patient's chronic dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and rectovaginal tenderness raise concern for endometriosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to your clinic because she has been unable to conceive for 2 years. She reports monthly episodes of pelvic and back pain with painful diarrhea for the past 6 years. She takes naproxen for the pain, which provides some relief. Her menses have been regular every 28 days since menarche at age 11 and last for 7 days. She is sexually active with her husband and does not use contraception. Pelvic and rectal examinations are normal. A hysterosalpingogram is unremarkable. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of her symptoms?

choices.text: Smooth muscle tumor arising from the myometrium.
Increased secretion of androgens and luteinizing hormone.
Endometrial tissue outside the uterine cavity.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Leiomyoma and leiomyosarcomas are smooth muscle tumors of the uterus that are usually small and asymptomatic. If symptoms do occur, they depend on the size and location of the tumor and can include abnormal menstruation. The exact mechanism of hypermenorrhea is not fully understood but probably involves abnormal venous drainage and prostaglandin production as well as enlargement of the uterine cavity. However, neither leiomyomas nor leiomyosarcomas are associated with diarrhea.

B) INCORRECT:

Sexually transmitted infections, especially gonorrhea and/or chlamydia, can cause inflammation of the fallopian tubes and lead to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Chronic PID can also manifest with episodic pelvic pain and infertility (secondary to scarring of the fallopian tubes preventing ova transit to the uterus). However, a hysterosalpingogram would show a sudden interruption of contrast media if fallopian tube scarring was present. Furthermore, PID would not account for this patient's recurrent diarrhea.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased androgen secretion and elevated luteinizing hormone are characteristics of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Patients with PCOS present with hirsutism and anovulation. This patient, however, has regular menstrual cycles.

D) CORRECT:

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterine cavity, most commonly in the fallopian tubes, ovaries, intestines, and/or bladder. Like the endometrium in the uterine cavity, this tissue reacts to the hormone cycle, proliferating under the influence of estrogen. Patients typically present with abdominal pain that worsens before the onset of menses. Depending on the location of the endometrial tissue, most likely rectovaginal in this case, symptoms such as diarrhea, dyschezia, and hematochezia can also occur.

Patients with endometriosis are usually treated with NSAIDs and continuous hormonal contraceptives. NSAIDs can be used alone if pregnancy is desired. In severe cases, GnRH agonists and estrogen-progestin OCPs may be indicated.

Key learning point: Endometriosis, characterized by endometrial tissue outside the uterus, commonly causes cyclical pelvic pain, gastrointestinal symptoms, and infertility in reproductive-age women.

E) INCORRECT:

Primary ovarian failure causes anovulation, amenorrhea, and infertility. Although this patient has not been able to conceive for 2 years, she has a regular menstrual cycle. Moreover, primary ovarian failure is not usually associated with pelvic pain or diarrhea.
questions.hint: It is likely that this patient's episodes of diarrhea and pelvic and back pain occur at a certain time in her menstrual cycle.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of intermittent pelvic pain. She reports that the pain worsens during menstruation, sexual intercourse, and defecation. Menarche was at age 12, and her menstrual cycles are regular every 28 days. On pelvic examination, there is rectovaginal tenderness. Transvaginal ultrasonography reveals several cysts in both ovaries. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is a bacterial infection of the upper female reproductive tract that can cause dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia. However, this condition does not typically cause dyschezia or ovarian cysts. In addition, this patient does not have a history of sexually transmitted infections. Moreover, she does not have other typical manifestations of PID, such as cervical motion tenderness, purulent discharge, and signs of infection on ultrasound (e.g., free fluid, hydrosalpinx).

B) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) can cause multiple, cystic proliferations within the ovaries. However, this condition does not typically cause pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, or dyschezia. In addition, this patient lacks typical manifestations of PCOS, such as hirsutism, acne, and irregular menses.

C) INCORRECT:

Uterine leiomyomas are benign smooth muscle tumors that can cause dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and dyschezia. However, they appear on ultrasound as concentric, hypoechoic, heterogeneous masses located in or on the uterus; leiomyomas do not form in the ovaries or cause ovarian cysts.

D) CORRECT:

Endometriosis is a condition characterized by ectopic endometrial tissue. The proliferation of this tissue in response to the normal hormone cycle results in cyclical menstrual pain, as seen in this patient. Endometriosis can involve several parts of the female reproductive tract (e.g., the rectouterine pouch, broad ligament, rectovaginal septum, vagina) and result in dyspareunia, dyschezia, and rectovaginal tenderness on pelvic examination. Ovarian endometriomas (chocolate cysts), which are cyst-like structures that contain blood, fluid, and menstrual debris, are also common.

Key learning point: Endometriosis is characterized by ectopic endometrial tissue causing cyclical pelvic pain, dyspareunia, dyschezia, rectovaginal tenderness, and ovarian endometriomas (chocolate cysts) visible on imaging.

E) INCORRECT:

Adenomyosis is a common cause of dysmenorrhea in women of reproductive age. However, this condition does not typically cause dyspareunia or dyschezia. In addition, pelvic examination of patients with adenomyosis typically shows a tender, uniformly enlarged uterus rather than rectovaginal tenderness, and ultrasound typically shows myometrial cysts, not ovarian cysts.
questions.hint: This patient presents with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, dyschezia, and ovarian cysts. The underlying condition is a common cause of infertility.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with worsening pelvic pain over 18 months. She reports that the pain is most severe in the 2–3 days before menstruation; she is taking regular acetaminophen with limited improvement in pain. She tried oral contraceptives for 3 months without improvement. Physical examination shows bilateral adnexal tenderness and an indurated rectovaginal septum. Vital signs are normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Order MRI pelvis with and without IV contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Danazol is an advanced treatment option typically used if initial medical therapy is unsuccessful. Initial imaging should be obtained first to assess the extent of disease and assess for endometriomas before considering advanced medical treatments.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Transvaginal ultrasound is the appropriate initial imaging study for suspected endometriosis. This patient's presentation of cyclical pelvic pain that worsens before menstruation, progressive dysmenorrhea, bilateral adnexal tenderness, and an indurated rectovaginal septum strongly suggests endometriosis. Transvaginal ultrasound can assess for ovarian endometriomas and other findings to guide further management.

C) INCORRECT:

CA-125 levels may be elevated in endometriosis, but this finding is nonspecific and thus not recommended for diagnosis. CA-125 levels may also be elevated in benign gynecologic conditions such as pelvic inflammatory disease and in malignancy.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI pelvis is indicated if ultrasound findings are normal or equivocal and surgery is being considered or deep infiltrating endometriosis is suspected. Transvaginal ultrasound is more affordable and accessible than MRI. MRI should be reserved as a second-line imaging modality.

E) INCORRECT:

Multimodal nonopioid analgesia is the preferred initial management for chronic noncancer pain. For chronic pain refractory to nonopioid management, opioid therapy may be considered only if the benefits outweigh the risks. Initial imaging should be obtained first to evaluate the extent of disease, and NSAIDs should be added to her pain management regimen.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old woman with a 5-year history of biopsy-proven endometriosis presents to the Outpatient Clinic with concerns after reading conflicting information online. She has been stable on medical therapy for pelvic pain but is anxious about her long-term risk of malignancy. She has no significant personal or family history of cancers. Physical examination is normal.
She specifically asks which type of malignancy she is more prone to due to her history of endometriosis. Which of the following best addresses her concern?

choices.text: Increased risk of epithelial ovarian cancer

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis is not associated with an increased risk of thyroid carcinoma. The established link is with certain ovarian cancers, not thyroid cancer. Risk factors for thyroid carcinoma, such as radiation exposure and genetic predispositions, are unrelated to endometriosis.

B) CORRECT:

Endometriosis is associated with an increased risk of epithelial ovarian cancer, particularly clear cell and endometrioid carcinomas. Chronic inflammation and recurrent hemorrhage in endometriosis create an environment conducive to cellular atypia and malignant transformation. This process involves oxidative stress, DNA damage, and genetic mutations, leading to neoplastic transformation of the ovarian epithelium. Epidemiologic studies support this association, highlighting the need for vigilant clinical surveillance in patients with endometriosis.

Key learning point: Endometriosis is associated with an increased risk of epithelial ovarian cancer, but it does not have a protective effect against cancer or a clear relationship with thyroid cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis is associated with a modestly increased risk of specific ovarian malignancies, particularly clear cell and endometrioid carcinomas. Chronic inflammation and hormonal influences in endometriosis contribute to this risk, despite the condition being benign and the patient's normal examination and negative family history.

D) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis does not confer protection against gynecologic malignancies. While hormonal therapies may reduce the risk of certain cancers, endometriosis itself is linked to an increased risk of specific ovarian cancers, particularly clear cell and endometrioid subtypes, due to chronic inflammation and oxidative stress.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman presents with progressively worsening pelvic pain during menses for the past year and difficulty conceiving for eight months. She has tried over-the-counter NSAIDs with minimal relief. Her menstrual cycles are regular. Pelvic examination reveals tenderness in the posterior fornix and nodularity along the uterosacral ligaments. A recent transvaginal ultrasound shows no abnormalities (see report).
Transvaginal ultrasound: No abnormalities
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hysterosalpingography evaluates uterine cavity abnormalities and tubal patency in infertility workups. However, it does not assess peritoneal lesions or endometriotic implants, which are likely causes of this patient's dysmenorrhea and uterosacral ligament nodularity. Direct visualization of the pelvis is more appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

High-dose progestins reduce pain in endometriosis by inducing decidualization and atrophy of ectopic tissue. However, they suppress ovulation, making them unsuitable for patients with infertility who wish to conceive. Medical therapy does not allow for direct visualization or removal of pelvic adhesions and implants, which is beneficial for reproductive concerns.

C) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic therapy is indicated for suspected infections like pelvic inflammatory disease, characterized by fever, abnormal discharge, and cervical motion tenderness. This patient has chronic, cyclical pelvic pain and infertility, with no signs of infection or acute inflammation, making antibiotics inappropriate.

D) CORRECT:

The presentation of secondary dysmenorrhea, infertility, and pelvic examination findings such as posterior fornix tenderness and uterosacral ligament nodularity suggests endometriosis. Transvaginal ultrasound may not detect superficial peritoneal implants, common in endometriosis. Diagnostic laparoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis, allowing direct visualization and potential histologic confirmation. It also offers the opportunity for therapeutic intervention, such as lesion ablation or excision, which can alleviate symptoms and improve fertility.

Key learning point: Severe dysmenorrhea and secondary infertility are commonly associated with endometriosis, a condition where endometrial tissue grows outside the uterus.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of intermittent pelvic pain. The pain is worse during menses, sexual intercourse, and when defecating. Menarche occurred at 12 years of age, and menses occur at regular 28-day intervals. Pelvic examination shows rectovaginal tenderness. Transvaginal ultrasonography shows several cysts in the ovaries bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adenomyosis is a common cause of dysmenorrhea in women of reproductive age. However, this condition does not typically cause dyspareunia or dyschezia. In addition, pelvic examination of patients with adenomyosis typically shows a tender, uniformly enlarged uterus rather than rectovaginal tenderness, and ultrasound typically shows myometrial cysts, not ovarian cysts.

B) INCORRECT:

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is a bacterial infection of the upper female reproductive tract that can cause dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia. However, this condition does not typically cause dyschezia or ovarian cysts. In addition, this patient does not have a history of sexually transmitted infections. Moreover, she does not have other typical manifestations of PID, such as cervical motion tenderness, purulent discharge, and signs of infection on ultrasound (e.g., free fluid, hydrosalpinx).

C) INCORRECT:

Uterine leiomyomas are benign smooth muscle tumors that can cause dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and dyschezia. However, they appear on ultrasound as concentric, hypoechoic, heterogeneous masses located in or on the uterus; leiomyomas do not form in the ovaries or cause ovarian cysts.

D) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) can cause multiple, cystic proliferations within the ovaries. However, this condition does not typically cause pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, or dyschezia. In addition, this patient lacks typical manifestations of PCOS, such as hirsutism, acne, and irregular menses.

E) CORRECT:

Endometriosis is a condition characterized by ectopic endometrial tissue. The proliferation of this tissue in response to the normal hormone cycle results in cyclical menstrual pain, as seen in this patient. Endometriosis can involve several parts of the female reproductive tract (e.g., the rectouterine pouch, broad ligament, rectovaginal septum, vagina) and result in dyspareunia, dyschezia, and rectovaginal tenderness on pelvic examination. Ovarian endometriomas (chocolate cysts), which are cyst-like structures that contain blood, fluid, and menstrual debris, are also common.
questions.hint: This patient presents with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, dyschezia, and ovarian cysts. The underlying condition is a common cause of infertility.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 4, comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of painful, heavy menses. Menses previously occurred at regular 28-day intervals and lasted 3 days with normal flow. They now last 7–8 days and the flow is heavy with the passage of clots. Pelvic examination shows a tender, uniformly enlarged, flaccid uterus consistent in size with an 8-week gestation. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?

choices.text: Endometrial tissue within the uterine wall

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pedunculated endometrial masses (a type of uterine polyp) are endometrial overgrowths that can cause menorrhagia if they are highly vascularized. However, uterine polyps do not cause symmetrical enlargement of the uterus.

B) CORRECT:

Ectopic endometrial glandular tissue within the uterine wall (myometrium) is characteristic of uterine adenomyosis, which has a peak incidence in women 40–50 years of age. The ectopic endometrial tissue induces hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the surrounding myometrium and results in a symmetrically enlarged uterus that is similar to a uterus in pregnancy. Secretions from ectopic glands within the myometrium cause pain and cramping, which become worse during menses.

The definitive diagnosis of adenomyosis requires histological examination of a hysterectomy specimen. Although MRI and uterine biopsy could further support the diagnosis, these tools would not provide any additional benefits for treatment. Hormonal treatment with GnRH agonists or oral contraceptives may provide symptomatic relief. Hysterectomy is the only definitive therapy and the preferred treatment in severe disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Malignant transformation of endometrial tissue is seen in endometrial carcinoma, the most common cancer of the female genital tract in the US, which can also present with menorrhagia. However, endometrial carcinoma is unlikely because it usually does not cause uterine enlargement in early stages, the average age at diagnosis is 70 years, and this patient has no risk factors (e.g., nulliparity, metabolic syndrome, history of increased estrogen exposure).

D) INCORRECT:

Abnormal thickening of endometrial tissue with no evidence of atypia or invasion on endometrial biopsy is characteristic for endometrial hyperplasia, which can also present with abnormal uterine bleeding. However, endometrial hyperplasia is much more common in nulliparous women and does not involve a symmetrically enlarged uterus.

E) INCORRECT:

Endometriotic cell implants in the ovaries, fallopian tubes, and/or cervix are found in patients with endometriosis, a condition that can also cause dysmenorrhea. However, in endometriosis, the uterus is not enlarged and this patient lacks other features caused by ectopic endometrial tissue, e.g., rectovaginal tenderness and dyspareunia.

F) INCORRECT:

Benign smooth muscle tumors within the uterine wall (myometrium) are characteristic for fibroids, which can also cause menorrhagia. However, rather than manifesting with a uniformly enlarged uterus, fibroids tend to manifest with an irregularly enlarged and firm uterus. Fibroids that are especially large or numerous may cause constant pelvic pressure and pain rather than menstrual pain exclusively. They are much more common in nulliparous women.
questions.hint: Menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea in a multiparous woman with a diffusely enlarged and tender uterus suggest adenomyosis.
